item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Murong Xuecun Says He Is Target of Twitter Smear Campaign
item.description: Articles that are being spread on Twitter portray Murong Xuecun, a prominent author and critic of the Communist Party, as a sexually promiscuous, wife-beating, money-hungry hypocrite.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Murong Xuecun, an author and critic of the Communist Party, in 2011.

item.title: U.S. Launches New Airstrikes on ISIS to Protect Dam in Iraq
item.description: The airstrikes were aimed at stopping militants from seizing the Haditha Dam and preventing the possibility of floodwaters flowing toward Baghdad.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER, KAREEM FAHIM and C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: A Kurdish fighter near a checkpoint west of Erbil, Iraq, on Sunday. In Anbar Province, control of the Haditha Dam was at stake.

item.title: Small Meteorite Hits Managua
item.description: A predicted asteroid appears to have created the meteorite, which left a crater 16 feet deep.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Officials in Qatar Confirm Detention of Britons Researching Migrant Labor
item.description: Krishna Upadhyaya, a researcher, and Ghimire Gundev, a photographer, had been reported missing on Aug. 31, that same day they were preparing to leave the country.”
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:credit: Global Network for Rights and Development (GNRD), via Associated Press
item.media:description: Photographs from the Global Network for Rights and Development show Ghimire Gundev, left, and Krishna Upadhyaya.

item.title: Qatar’s Support of Extremists Alienates Allies Near and Far
item.description: Qatar has helped support a spectrum of Islamist groups by providing safe haven, diplomatic mediation, financial aid and, in certain instances, weapons.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: The skyline of Doha, the capital. Several people identified by the United States as private fund-raisers for Al Qaeda’s Syrian affiliate operate freely in the city.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Wealthy Chinese Travelers Lining Up to Blast Off
item.description: China is set to become the world’s largest market for the fledgling space tourism industry.
item.dc:creator: By CAO LI
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheng Tianxing, a tea trader, bought a $100,000 ticket for a trip on a commercially operated flight to go 64 miles above Earth.

item.title: Destroying ISIS May Take Years, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: The Obama administration is preparing to carry out a phased campaign requiring a sustained effort that could last until after President Obama has left office, according to officials.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT, MICHAEL R. GORDON and HELENE COOPER

item.title: Palestinian Leader Assails Hamas, Calling Unity Pact Into Question
item.description: At an Arab League gathering, President Mahmoud Abbas accused Islamists of running a shadow government in Gaza despite a reconciliation pact with his Fatah faction.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: President Mahmoud Abbas, right, at an Arab League meeting in Cairo on Sunday. He accused Hamas of defiance in Gaza.

item.title: Forte Dei Marmi Journal: Despite Sanctions, Cash Keeps Flowing at Playground for Russia’s Rich
item.description: Business owners in seaside resort towns like Italy’s Forte dei Marmi worry that further sanctions could hurt business, but so far the reach of big Russian money seems little affected.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Forte dei Marmi, a seaside resort town in Italy, is a popular spot with wealthy Russians.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia Face Gaps in a Truce and a Chasm on the Issues
item.description: Both sides agreed to a “decentralization of power” in Ukraine in the terms of a truce agreement, but just what form that may take remains one issue of contention.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A basement bunker at a technical college in Yasinovataya, Ukraine, doubled as a bedroom.

item.title: The Media Equation: With Videos of Killings, ISIS Hones Social Media as a Weapon
item.description: The videos serve as both propaganda and time machine, trying to wipe away centuries of civilization and suggest that the dreamed-of caliphate flourishes and blood is cheap currency.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID CARR
item.media:credit: SITE Intelligence Group, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An screen grab taken from a video released by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

item.title: With Schools Doubling as Shelters in Northern Iraq, Classes Wait
item.description: More than 130,000 people have moved into 650 schools, carving out homes while posing a problem for the government this academic year.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Pakistani Democracy on Its Knees
item.description: The protests may partly be about politicking and power-grabbing, but the people's grievances are only too real.
item.dc:creator: By ALI DAYAN HASAN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Who Killed the Israeli Left?
item.description: The outside world backed a small political minority, making it even more isolated at home.
item.dc:creator: By SHMUEL ROSNER

item.title: Oil Scandal Erupts Again as Brazilians Near Election
item.description: A former executive at Petrobras, now in jail, testified that many top political figures were involved in a kickback scheme, according to a magazine report.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: As Polls Tighten, Britain Promises Scots More Self-Rule if They Reject Independence
item.description: With pro-union advocates losing ground in polls, a British official said there would be a plan for greater political and fiscal autonomy if Scots vote “no” on Sept. 18.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: English residents of Scotland who support Scottish independence offered free tea and cake on Sunday at a border rest stop near Berwick-upon-Tweed.

item.title: Natural Dam Collapses in Nepal, Washing Away Bridges
item.description: The dam created by a huge landslide last month across the Sankoshi River unleashed a wall of water that caused no casualties but might be a danger to villages in India.
item.dc:creator: By BHADRA SHARMA and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Afghan Court Wastes No Time Sentencing 7 to Death in Rape Case
item.description: Four women were raped, robbed and beaten by a gang of 10 men, seven of whom were captured and convicted of adultery and armed robbery in a swift trial Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and FAZAL MUZHARY
item.media:description: One of four women raped by a group of men attended a court hearing in Kabul, Afghanistan.

item.title: International Education: A Missionary for Liberal Arts
item.description: Bard College has become an unlikely champion of liberal education in countries known for their volatility and political upheaval.
item.dc:creator: By KARIN FISCHER | THE CHRONICLE OF HIGHER EDUCATION
item.media:description: Leon Botstein, second from left, the president of Bard College.

item.title: International Education: Canadian Universities Explore Range of Real Estate Careers
item.description: Several programs aim to show that the field offers a wide range of options.
item.dc:creator: By ELAINE SMITH

item.title: Obama to Present Case for Broader U.S. Mission Against Militants
item.description: In an interview on NBC, President Obama said he would speak to the nation on Wednesday to try to make a case for launching a wider United States-led offensive against ISIS in the Middle East.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama will speak to the nation on Wednesday to make his case for expanding the United States-led offensive against ISIS.

item.title: Cease-Fire in Ukraine Holds, but Soldiers and Residents Doubt It Will Last
item.description: The cease-fire between the Ukrainian government and Russian-backed separatists held on Saturday, but some violations were reported, and soldiers and civilians doubted that calm would prevail.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family prepared to flee their home in the southeastern Ukrainian village of Lebedinskoye after hearing explosions nearby.

item.title: North Korea Says It Will Put American on Trial
item.description: Matthew Todd Miller is accused of shredding his tourist visa and demanding asylum, which the North says is a “hostile act” against the country.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Building Good Will in a Troubled Afghan District, but Not Without a Fight
item.description: A day trip to a troubled district with America’s elite troops and Afghan government and military officials was characterized by the absurd and unexpected, features of the war in the country.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Wealthy Chinese Travelers Lining Up to Blast Off
item.description: China is set to become the world’s largest market for the fledgling space tourism industry.
